abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is highly
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Performances by
            the Bank, and the Borrower were also highly satisfactory,
            for the project was comprehensively well prepared, enabling
            up-front resolution of complex issues, and, the
            establishment of the Jamuna Multipurpose Bridge Authority
            provided the necessary financial, managerial, and ownership
            support. But, regardless of success, lessons drawn from the
            project suggest that: 1) the milestone decision meetings
            (MDM) proved to be extremely effective through its
            systematic approach in resolving, and staying focused on
            specific issues, and, it is thus suggested that MDM should
            become integrated into project supervision, even if it means
            higher supervision costs; 2) since projects involving large
            civil works, require land acquisition, as well as
            structural, and vegetative clearing, the practice of
            requiring substantial site readiness before consent of civil
            works, should become the norm. But greater coordination
            between the physical preparation, and that of the social
            components' will be required, so that resettlement, and
            compensation support becomes effective prior to
            displacement; 3) co-financing, in addition to counterpart
            funds, proved effective in funding such a complex project,
            and useful in reducing financial risks, but co-financing
            partnerships should ensure that the agreed modus operandi is
            clearly defined.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Jamuna Bridge Project :
            Request for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Request for Inspection of the Jamuna
            Bridge Project in Bangladesh states that the Bank has
            violated its own policies and procedures regarding this
            project. The Requesters, the Jamuna Char Integrated
            Development Project (JCDP), give a history of the Jamuna
            Bridge Project and express concern over the construction of
            the bridge, which will require the resettlement of more
            people than originally thought.  The people that live on the
            char, or small islands in the Jamuna River, will need to be
            resettled as a result of the bridge construction, but their
            resettlement was not included in the original plan. The
            Requesters state that the Bank's policy disallows
            involuntary resettlement, but the potential threat of
            displacement to the char people has not been taken into
            account. Major concerns involve guide bunds that would cause
            the river levels to rise and flood the char people's
            land and homes. The Requesters note that most of the people
            that would be affected only heard about the construction of
            the Jamuna bridge through hear-say. While there have been
            plans to resettle people, the land designated for the
            resettlement  can only accommodate approximately 20 percent
            of the people that will need land as a result of the
            construction.  The JCDP states that agriculture, social
            connections and livelihood would be destroyed by the
            resettlement and destruction of the char lands.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Jamuna Bridge Project :
            Management Response

abstracts.cdata!:
The Management Response to the Request
            for Inspection of the Jamuna Bridge Project in Bangladesh
            addresses the concerns that the interests and well-being of
            the char people, people that live on small islands in the
            river, are not being attended to. The disruption of river
            life as a result of bridge construction is noted and the
            Response states that planning for the bridge has been under
            careful consideration and examination and that since
            building is only allowable during the dry season, a phased
            approach was adopted to ensure that the erosion and flooding
            were properly observed.  The resettlement areas, the
            Requesters allege, are too small and do not allow enough
            room for all of the people to be resettled. The Response
            states that the idea for resettlement incentives is in
            effect and that people will be allowed to resettle
            themselves on nearby farmland.  The Management Response
            allows for each allegation to be responded to by the
            Management and the Government of Bangladesh.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Jamuna Bridge Project :
            Eligibility Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Eligibility Report for the Jamuna
            Bridge Project in Bangladesh briefly summarizes the Request
            for Inspection and the Management Response. The Jamuna
            Bridge Project, meant to span the Jamuna River, will require
            the resettlement of the char people, who live on small
            mid-channel islands known as chars. The Request alleges that
            the char people were not included in the planning and
            implementation of resettlement and the environmental
            measures that surround the bridge construction. The main
            concerns of the Request outline involuntary resettlement of
            the people and the lack of involvement of the char people.
            The Management Response maintains that it adhered to the
            correct policies and procedures and that a phased approach
            to the construction was implemented to lessen the effects on
            the surrounding area and people. After examining the details
            of the Request, the Panel feels that the Request meets the
            eligibility criteria and reflects legitimate concerns of
            people that may be adversely affected by the project. The
            Panel feels that the policies and procedures for
            resettlement have not been properly followed. The Panel
            feels that many changed should be made in order to insure
            remedies for emerging problems. The Inspection Panel
            concludes that an investigation of the matters alleged in
            the Request is not warranted at this time.
